headline: Inside Politics
subHeadline: Biden, Trump Clinch Nominations to Set Up White House Rematch; Polls Say More Voters Believe Trump's Policies Have Helped Them Compared to How Many Believe Biden's Policies Have Helped; RFK Jr. Says He's Picked Running Mate, Will Announce It This Month; Less Than Half the Republican Conference Expected to Attend This Week's Annual Retreat; Ken Buck to Resign Next Week; Paralyzed Congress, Historically Few Laws Passed Last Year. Aired 12:30-1p ET

utterances.speaker: DANA BASH, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Presidential rematch is on, but both President Biden and Former President Trump are facing headwinds in their bids to recapture the White House. For President Biden, it is maintaining his 2020 coalition. For President Trump, it is winning back the Republican voters who abandoned him in this year's primaries. And then there are the independent candidates.Joining me to discuss is Democratic Pollster Celinda Lake and Republican Pollster Ed Goeas. They are co-authors of the book, "A Question of RESPECT: Bringing Us Together in a Deeply Divided Nation." Here it is. You see it there, here it is. Nice to see both. I'm so glad that you can come on. (CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: I want to talk with kind of the big picture as we head into the next eight months. What do you think, based on the data that you have, based on the surveys that you're doing, that voters are really going to care the most about, particularly in these key swing states? I'll start with you.

utterances.speaker: CELINDA LAKE, DEMOCRATIC POLLSTER
utterances.sentences: I think three things. I think they're going to care about the character of the people. And the more that people get exposed, particularly women get exposed to Donald Trump, the less they like him. So he has actually benefited from being off of Twitter and being less than the limelight. And I think this exposure is going to work to Biden's advantage. They're going to care about the economy and we are fighting hard to get people's perceptions about the economy better and they are improving. But, we got to keep on that. And they're going to care about abortion and that's going to work in our favor with a lot of key swing votes.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: I was waiting to see if you were going to mention that, I was to ask you that.

utterances.speaker: LAKE
utterances.sentences: Absolutely. BASH

utterances.speaker: GOEAS
utterances.sentences: We are already beginning to see some signs of moving in that direction. And you see the jobs number is good, you see inflation down some, but more importantly, you see other parts of the economy that's thriving and doing very well. And if that comes to a head in eight months, it is coming to a head just as the two conventions are going on this summer, which means that the messaging may not be there for Republicans and may be there in a big way for Democrats.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: GOEAS
utterances.sentences: A month later.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Well, they've been trying to message the Democrats, but people aren't actually feeling that. You think that they would actually, based on your experience, start to --

utterances.speaker: GOEAS
utterances.sentences: It is going to take till summer before all that kind of sinks in, if it sinks in.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: OK. Let's do something I know you all love to do. Look at the cross tabs --

utterances.speaker: LAKE
utterances.sentences: Excellent.(LAUGH)

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: -- at the demographics and how each -- many of them are looking at these two candidates. This is in New York Times and the question is about whether or not the president's policies have helped you personally. On men, Donald Trump is winning. On women, Donald Trump is winning. White, Donald Trump is winning. Black, Donald Trump is winning. Hispanic, Donald Trump is winning. Interesting, these are registered voters.Now, let's look at the question of age. Donald Trump is winning on the young people, on 30 to 44, on 45 to 64, and also on 65. What do the margins there tell you and just the fact that across the board he seems to be doing well? I mean, it kind of matches up with the head- to-head which does show, even though it is margin of error, Donald Trump doing better than Joe Biden right now?

utterances.speaker: LAKE
utterances.sentences: Yeah. So basically, even Donald Trump voters are more energized, which is common when you have a primary, but there's nothing like Donald Trump to energize Joe Biden voters. What is really interesting about those numbers though, Dana, I think is how many people refused to make a choice. I think both are a problem. And I think the key voting groups are going to be the people that dislike both of these candidates. 17 percent to 21 percent of the electorate right now, when pushed, they vote for Joe Biden. That's the secret sauce for the election.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Or they could stay home.

utterances.speaker: LAKE
utterances.sentences: Or they could stay home or vote third party.

utterances.speaker: GOEAS
utterances.sentences: And I get very nervous looking at one poll because (inaudible).

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Yeah, of course, so do we. But we just wanted to give a snapshot.

utterances.speaker: GOEAS
utterances.sentences: But if you look at the average --

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: GOEAS
utterances.sentences: -- of -- really since the beginning of the year, that Trump has never had more than a four-point lead. And at some points, Biden spin up to a two-point lead. But it is basically, one point one way or the other within the margin of error. I think you have to take a step back here and say, over 70 percent of voters wish this was not happening --

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Well --

utterances.speaker: GOEAS
utterances.sentences: -- in terms of the two candidates.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: OK, so on that. You both have kind of brought up in your own ways questions of alternatives. Let's talk about Robert F. Kennedy Jr. He put out a potential running mate list, includes Aaron Rodgers, NFL quarterback; Jesse Ventura, Former Minnesota Governor; Tulsi Gabbard, Former Congresswoman; Rand Paul Kentucky Senator -- I'm not sure he is so interested though -- Andrew Yang, former presidential candidate; Mike Rowe, Tony Robbins, and Trisha Lindsey.I guess, the first question as we talk about potential running mates to see if that will sway anybody, are Democrats adequately worried about the RFK factor, especially if he gets on the ballot in some of these key swing states?

utterances.speaker: LAKE
utterances.sentences: I think so. I think Democrats are very worried about third-party candidates in general because they pull from Joe Biden. What we found though is people are reading into RFK, the old Kennedy name and in fact, half the voters confused him with his father. Democratic primary voters are revealing when they found out that he was an anti-vaxxer, his checkered past on abortion, his choice of running mates, those are not Democrats. I think that his numbers will fall, but it is very formidable, very concerning, particularly among young people.

utterances.speaker: GOEAS
utterances.sentences: I think they're going to be a factor in terms of getting the vote higher. But I think what I'm saying with the third party and I think this is true who ever kind of comes forward in the next couple of months or weeks, is that what they're doing is bringing out voters that has pretty much decided they're going to sit at home and not vote any way. BASH

utterances.speaker: GOEAS
utterances.sentences: So, it doesn't really change anything. I think the bigger question is, those voters, as you mentioned earlier, for example, who voted against Donald Trump in the primary, are they going to stay home? Are they going to turn out and vote for Biden? And that is one of the key questions, even more so than third-party candidates.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: So interesting. Well, there is no question of the respect between the two of you, Republican and Democrat, great conversation. Please come back.

utterances.speaker: LAKE
utterances.sentences: Thank you for having us.

utterances.speaker: GOEAS
utterances.sentences: Thank you so much.

utterances.speaker: LAKE
utterances.sentences: And great respect for you.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: And before we kick off this conversation, I just want to play for our viewers, who might have missed, my conversation with Ken Buck. This is as he was making the announcement that surprised his own leadership, that he was going to not just retire at the end of the Congress, but he was going to resign at the end of next week. Here's why he said he is doing that.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) REP. KEN BUCK (R-CO): But a lot of this is personal and that's the problem, instead of having decorum, instead of operating in a professional manner, this place has just devolved into this bickering and nonsense and not really doing the job for the American people.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Is it that bad that you're saying I'm done?

utterances.speaker: BUCK
utterances.sentences: It is the worst year of the nine years and three months that I've been in Congress. And having talked to former members, it is the worst year in 40, 50 years to be in Congress.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: And I said, do have anything else to add? He said bye.(LAUGH)

utterances.speaker: JACKIE KUCINICH, WASHINGTON BUREAU CHIEF, THE BOSTON GLOBE
utterances.sentences: So, I haven't seen anything that encapsulates what is going on at the Republican retreat quite as much as what Olivia Beavers from POLITICO tweeted yesterday. I'd rather sit down with Hannibal Lecter and eat my own liver.(LAUGH)

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.sentences: Said one House Republican when asked if they were attending the House GOP retreat.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Oh my God.

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Olivia, for that. But I think the -- we've seen this throughout the year, right? I mean, there is a tendency to blame Speaker Johnson for not having fostered a lot of unity, but let's not forget how this year started out with all of the Kevin McCarthy drama. So, was that last year?EDWARD-ISAAC DOVERE, CNN SENIOR REPORTER: That was last year.

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.sentences: That was last year, I'm sorry, this Congress -- forgive me -- started out with the Kevin McCarthy drama. They've never really been able to work as a team here. And we are just seeing it play out with smaller and smaller and smaller numbers at this point, which is (ph) harder.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: And I just want to underscore, what we are talking about isn't sort of the House. We are talking about Republicans --

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: -- who are in charge of the House. And they are really the people who are talking about the liver eating situation.(LAUGH).

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: After Ken Buck leaves next Friday, this is what the breakdown is going to be. 218 Republicans, 213 Democrats, four vacancies. So, this is just an example of how the tensions are made even worse --

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: -- when it comes to how Mike Johnson, the speaker, and other members of leadership, can manage these guys and women because they have such a narrow margin. It is almost non-existent.LEIGH ANN CALDWELL, EARLY 202 CO-AUTHOR, THE WASHINGTON POST: It is pretty much non-existent and that is why Speaker Johnson isn't able to manage these guys. He's a person -- leader with little experience leading, but he has lost control of the majority. He's not able to pass anything with Republican votes. Now, they have to what they do, suspend the rules and everything, even messaging bills that are supposed to be good and easy for Republicans, half to -- can't pass unless it involves Democratic votes. And so, it is, you have the faction of the party who is mad at people for ousting Kevin McCarthy. You have the people who have no relationship with Mike Johnson. You have someone like Patrick McHenry who has been in Congress for a long time, and he is ready to burn it all down on his way out as well, and he's very much lately -- had been --

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: ANN CALDWELL
utterances.sentences: -- a member of the establishment.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: I mean, I could see watching this and saying, well, that's so bad that because the majority is so narrow, they have to work together in a bipartisan way. I mean, TikTok that happened this morning. I mean, we've never seen anything like that or we haven't seen anything like that in recent -- in recent times. That -- but that is definitely the exception, not the rule.And Isaac, I just want you to look at this graph which shows you how little the House Republican majority has gotten done when it comes to bills into law. Only 27 in the first year of this session -- 27, that is the lowest by far in almost 30 years, three times lower than the next highest. And I think that includes like post offices.

utterances.speaker: ANN CALDWELL
utterances.sentences: It does.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: DOVERE
utterances.sentences: Ukraine funding, Israel funding, government funding --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Oh, that, yeah. DOVERE

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Well, they've been working really hard to (inaudible).

utterances.speaker: DOVERE
utterances.sentences: Really?

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: DOVERE
utterances.sentences: And -- but with this kind of margin, it's a question of what is even the point of coming back.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Four-time NBA champion Steph Curry is considering his future after basketball. The 35-year-old told CBS he could be open to a future in politics when his playing days are over.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: JERICKA DUNCAN, CBS NEWS NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Steph Curry for president?

utterances.speaker: STEPHEN CURRY, GOLDEN STATE WARRIORS POINT GUARD
utterances.sentences: Thank you all for welcoming us here.

utterances.speaker: DUNCAN
utterances.sentences: Yay? Nay? Maybe?

utterances.speaker: CURRY
utterances.sentences: Maybe.

utterances.speaker: DUNCAN
utterances.sentences: You have an interest in politics?

utterances.speaker: CURRY
utterances.sentences: I have an interest in leveraging every part of my influence for good in the way that I can, so if that's the way to do it, then I'm not saying the presidency, but if that's --

utterances.speaker: DUNCAN
utterances.sentences: You said maybe.

utterances.speaker: CURRY
utterances.sentences: -- if that's politics, that's maybe is what I'm saying. If politics is the way that you can create meaningful change, or if there's another way outside of politics that we can do --

utterances.speaker: DUNCAN
utterances.sentences: You're not ruling it out.

utterances.speaker: CURRY
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: DUNCAN
utterances.sentences: 2028, you never know.(LAUGH)

utterances.speaker: CURRY
utterances.sentences: Not that soon.

utterances.speaker: DUNCAN
utterances.sentences: Not that soon, OK.(END VIDEO CLIP)
